page.title: 12Woodlands in Leighfield 2
page.content: Launde Park Wood (803038) is 140 acres of ancient woodland stretching from a ridge at 600ft above sea level down to the valley of the River Chater. The wood is owned by the Diocese of Leicester and managed by the Forestry Commission.Before 1959 the wood was coppiced ash, elm and oak with a rich and varied coppiced shrub layer containing much hazel. In 1959 the Forestry Commission began felling and replanting the southern part of the wood with oak, beech and western red cedar to the detriment of its ecological interest.The northern part was unaffected and still supports bluebells and wild garlic as well as rarer plants such as toothwort. The tracks in the southern part were resurfaced with crushed limestone so introducing alien flora such as wild parsnip and centaury.
